title: Islamophobic attack data to be collected
text:
Data on attacks against British Muslims collected for first time Kate Allen, Political Correspondent ©Getty 
Police are to collect data on Islamophobic attacks against British Muslims for the first time as David Cameron launches a fresh attempt to tackle extremism. 
The move will put anti-Muslim hate crimes on a par with anti-Semitic attacks, the prime minister will say as he hosts the first meeting of his new community engagement forum in Downing Street on Tuesday. More Holyrood to get new powers over welfare 
The group will look at the best ways for the government to tackle extremism. 
Mr Cameron is also set to announce new funding to cover the cost of stepping up security at religious buildings including mosques. 
The prime minister has accused some segments of the Muslim community of “quietly condoning” Islamist ideology, and said that non-religious groups were shirking their duties to keep the country safe. 
Speaking in July in what aides billed as his most significant speech on Islamic militancy to date, he complained that universities were failing to challenge “creeping extremism” on their campuses, and internet companies were not doing enough to help the authorities identify extremists who operated online. 
Mr Cameron urged broadcasters to give more airtime to moderate Muslims so they could show the country a more balanced view of their faith. 
He also promised funding, protection and “political representation” to UK Muslim groups that demonstrated an adherence to British values. 
The creation of a new category for crimes against Muslims will make it easier for police, prosecutors and local councils to understand the prevalence of such attacks, Mr Cameron believes. His government intends to be “as bold in delivering social reform as we have been in economic”, he said. 
“A big social problem we need to tackle to rebuild Britain as an even greater country is extremism,” he said. 
Religious hate crimes increased by 44 per cent in the year to April 2014, and statistics due to be published on Tuesday are expected to show further increases.
